Commentaries: Saint, who survived the tourtures of Trdat and afterwards converted the Armenian king and people of his realm into Christianity. Also the first bishop of the Armenian church, ordained by Leontius of Caesaria. Accordic to the Arabic version of his martyrdom, he sent some bishops to the lands of Alans, Ivers and some other peoples of Caucasus and Near East, so he is shown not only as a baptist of Armenians

The king of Armenia (287-330) that at first, being pagan, tortured Gregory the Illuminator, Hripsime with other nuns, but was punished for that with an illness that turned him into a wild boar. to get cured, he was to free Gregory, bury killed Hrpsime with nuns and convert himself into Christianity. After curing and convertion he took measures to destroy pagan temples and spread the Chrisitanity around in Armenia. Followed Gregory at his consecration as an archbishop in Caesaria, met Constantine the Great in Rome to tell him about the convertion of Armenia into Christianity

Roman emperor that was looking for a wife and learnt about Hripsime, a Roman nun. But Hripsime together with Gayane and other nuns escaped from the pagan emperor to Armenia, so Diocletian asked Trdat, the Armenian king, to send Hripsime to him and to kill other nuns
The abbess of a Roman monastery, where Hripsime lived. She ran together with Hripsime (who was reluctant to marry pagans Diocletiian and Trdat) and other nuns from Rome to Armenia

Roman nun (from a family of believing kings) under the leadership of Gayane, that refused to marry pagan Diocletian and ran to Armenia together with Gayane and some other nuns, afterwards martyred by Trdat, whom she was also reluctant to marry
Armenian noblemen who was sent to Artaat in order to get tortured Gregory the Illuminator out of the pit
King of the Neo-Babylonian Empire, that lost his mind once and started grazing with beasts in the desert. The same happened with Armenian King Trdat that turned into a wild boar

Trdat's sister that saw a dream for several times, that Gregory the Illuminator is alive in the dungeon and he is only able to cure ill Trdat. Together with Tdrat's wife Ashkhen, she helped Trdat to make the burials of Hripsime and martyred nuns (carrying the soil in their dresses instead of baskets) and followed the king at the meeting with Petros the bishop and Gregory the Illuminator in Caesaria

Trdat's wife, that together with Xosrovidut helped Trdat to make the burials of Hripsime and martyred nuns (carrying the soil in their dresses instead of baskets) and followed the king at the meeting with Petros the bishop and Gregory the Illuminator in Caesaria

Saint patriarch and archbishop of Caesaria that consecrated Gregory the Illuminator as the patriarch of Armenia, gave him part of the relics of John the Baptist and asked Petros (in a letter) to accompany Gregory at his enthroning
Saint bishop of Sebastia that accompanied Gregory the Illuminator at his enthroning, sanctified the altars in new Armenian churches
Roman patrician, Trdat's tutor
An Iverian (Georgian) from Sebastia (Sivas) that was ordained metropolitan in order to consecrate the bishops in Iveria (Georgia)
A priest from Cappadokia that was sent by Gregory the Illuminator to Abkazians as a bishop
Native of Satał that was sent by Gregory the Illuminator to Alans as a bishop
One of the disciples of Gregory the Illuminator that was sent to Basean as a bishop
One of the disciples of Gregory the Illuminator that was sent to the land of Bikugs as a bishop
One of the disciples of Gregory the Illuminator that was sent to Ibakliret and Derzdan as a bishop
One of the disciples of Gregory the Illuminator that was sent to Daranałikʿ as a bishop
One of the disciples of Gregory the Illuminator that was sent to the land of Kuhanits as a bishop
One of the disciples of Gregory the Illuminator that was sent to as a bishop. In arabic verion of the martyrdom he is named as Khabib
One of the disciples of Gregory the Illuminator that was sent to the land, that belonged to the Mamikonean house, as a bishop
One of the disciples of Gegory the Illuminator that was sent to the land of Małχazkʿ as a bishop
The ruler of the land of Małχazkʿ
One of the disciples of Gregory the Illuminator that was sent to Sirag (Syria?) as a bishop
One of the disciples of Gregory the Illuminator that was sent to Kardalet as a bishop
One of the disciples of Gregory the Illuminator that was sent to Atrpatakan as a bishop
One of the disciples of Gregory the Illuminator that was sent to Aršamunikʿ as a bishop
Elder son of Gregory the Illuminatior, who is married and lived in Caesaria
Younger son of Gregory the Illuminator, a monk (lived far in the mountains) that represented Armenia at the Council of Nicaea and brought the new canons from the Council to Armenia
The ruler of the lands belonging to the Mamikonean house, whom (together with Tačat and Dat) Trdat asked to bring to him the sons of Gregory the Illuminator
The ruler of Ason (Ašocʿkʿ = Abotsi), whom (together with Tacates and Dat) Trdat asked to bring to him the sons of Gregory the Illuminator
Trdat's advisor (in arab version of the martyrdom - vizier), whom (together with Tacates and Dat) Trdat asked to bring to him the sons of Gregory the Illuminator

Roman emperor, who asked Trdat to tell him everything about the miracles of Gregory the Illuminator and king's miraculous healing in particular, and then told Trdat about his vision (probably of a cross) and him winning the battle (obviously the Battle of the Mulvian Bridge) after the vision. Afterwards he precided over the council in Nicaea

Roman bishop that converted Constantine the Great into Christianity. Movses Khorenatsi in his "History of Armenia" adds to this episode: "as it was said by Agathangelos". In the Armenian version of Agathangelos nothing is mentioned about this legend, whereas in the martyrdom of Gregory, Hripsime and Gayane (in Arabic) Constantine the Great tells Trdat in his letter about his consecration by Silvester
Patriarch of Rome at the time Trdat and Gregory the Illuminator visited Constantine the Great in the Roman empire
Roman empress, mother of Constantine the Great

Commentaries:
Athenogenes of Pedachthoe (of Sebasteia) — a general Christian saint (III century), a contemporary of Diocletian. A native of the city of Sebasteia, was born in a Christian family. At first he was a priest, then a chorespe of the Sebasteia. He distinguished himself with his miracles. Metropolitan of Sebasteia consecrated to the rank of bishop of  Pedachthoe. For the refusal to make a sacrifice to idols, the judge of the city sentenced his and his ten students to death and they were beheaded. Athenogenes' sister Maria (Mariam) was the wife of Gregory the Illuminator.

Armenians twice celebrate his memory day: once with the memory of St. John the Baptist, in honor of the transfer of their relics to Armenia - on Thursday, following the first week of the holiday of the Resurrection, on the second - on Tuesday of the second week after Vardavar (Epiphany).

Literature:
Агатангелос. История Армении. Пер. с древнеарм., вступ. статья и комментарий К.С. Тер-Давтян и С.С. Аревшатяна. Ер., Наири, 2004. - с. 245, 252.
Ագաթանգեղոս. Հայոց պատմություն / Քննական բնագիրը Գ. Տեր-Մկըրտչյանի և Ս. Կանայանցի; Աշխարհաբար թարգմ. և ծանոթագր. Ա. Ն. Տեր-Ղևոնդյանի. — Եր,։ Երևանի Համալս. Հրատ., 1983. — էջ. 470, 471, 484, 485. — (Ուսանողի գ-րան/Երևանի պետ. համալս.)
Commentaries: Albianos (Alvianos) — the son of a pagan priest, whom Gregory the Illuminator ordained the bishops and made the bishop of the royal court. According to Faustus of Byzantium (book 3, chap. 4), after the extermination of the Manavazyan clan, the Armenian king Khosrov gave him Manavazakert (Manazkert) “with all the borders and adjacent regions that are in the Euphrates River basin, in hereditary possession. The house of Albianos, before receiving Manazkert, had certain possessions in the edges of Taron”.

Literature:
Агатангелос. История Армении. Пер. с древнеарм., вступ. статья и комментарий К.С. Тер-Давтян и С.С. Аревшатяна. Ер., Наири, 2004. - с. 31, 56.

Commentaries: Anak — the father of Gregory the Illuminator from the Parthian family. He killed the Armenian king Khosrov Arshakuni.

Ագաթանգեղոս. Հայոց պատմություն / Քննական բնագիրը Գ. Տեր-Մկըրտչյանի և Ս. Կանայանցի; Աշխարհաբար թարգմ. և ծանոթագր. Ա. Ն. Տեր-Ղևոնդյանի. — Եր,։ Երևանի Համալս. Հրատ., 1983. — էջ. 24-27. — (Ուսանողի գ-րան/Երևանի պետ. համալս.)
Commentaries: Artashir I (180-239) — King of Persia since 226. The founder of the Sassanid dynasty.

Literature:
Агатангелос. История Армении. Пер. с древнеарм., вступ. статья и комментарий К.С. Тер-Давтян и С.С. Аревшатяна. Ер., Наири, 2004. - с. 248.
Ագաթանգեղոս. Հայոց պատմություն / Քննական բնագիրը Գ. Տեր-Մկըրտչյանի և Ս. Կանայանցի; Աշխարհաբար թարգմ. և ծանոթագր. Ա. Ն. Տեր-Ղևոնդյանի. — Եր,։ Երևանի Համալս. Հրատ., 1983. — էջ. 478-479. — (Ուսանողի գ-րան/Երևանի պետ. համալս.)
Commentaries:
Artawazd Mandakuni — sparapet of Greater Armenia (IV century); According to Movses Khorenatsi, he was belonged to the nakhararian family of Mandakuni .
Artawazd saved the young Tiridates (the son of the murdered Armenian king Khosrov I), taking him to the Roman Empire. As a result, the Persian king Artashir ordered to exterminate all representatives of the Mandakuni clan.
Upon the reign of Tiridates III,  Artawazd was given the post of commander of the Armenian troops .

Literature:
Агатангелос. История Армении. Пер. с древнеарм., вступ. статья и комментарий К.С. Тер-Давтян и С.С. Аревшатяна. Ер., Наири, 2004. - с. 29, 30.

Literature:

Commentaries: St. Gayane — the abbess of the Convent of St. Paul in Rome, the early Christian Armenian saint and the martyr, who fled along with the 37 virgins from Diocletian due to the unwillingness of St. Hripsime to marry the emperor and executed by order of Tiridates III due to a similar refusal of St. Hripsime to the King of Greater Armenia.

Literature:

Literature:
Агатангелос. История Армении. Пер. с древнеарм., вступ. статья и комментарий К.С. Тер-Давтян и С.С. Аревшатяна. Ер., Наири, 2004. - с. 248.

Commentaries:
Dat — a noble man and messenger of the of Greater Armenia Tiridates III. He was sent together with sparapet Artawazd and ishkhan of Ashotsk Tachat for two sons of Gregory the Illuminator, who were supposed to lead to the Armenian king.
In the Arab version of the "History of Armenia" Agatangelos Dat is mentioned as the "vizier of the king" of Tiridates.

Literature:
Агатангелос. История Армении. Пер. с древнеарм., вступ. статья и комментарий К.С. Тер-Давтян и С.С. Аревшатяна. Ер., Наири, 2004. - с. 59, 63, 250.

Commentaries: Eulalios (Eulalios) — one of the students of Gregory the Illuminator from the children of pagan priests, ordained in bishops in Basen in Armenia.

Literature:
Агатангелос. История Армении. Пер. с древнеарм., вступ. статья и комментарий К.С. Тер-Давтян и С.С. Аревшатяна. Ер., Наири, 2004. - с. 33-35, 250.
Ագաթանգեղոս. Հայոց պատմություն / Քննական բնագիրը Գ. Տեր-Մկըրտչյանի և Ս. Կանայանցի; Աշխարհաբար թարգմ. և ծանոթագր. Ա. Ն. Տեր-Ղևոնդյանի. — Եր,։ Երևանի Համալս. Հրատ., 1983. — էջ. 32-37, 482, 483. — (Ուսանողի գ-րան/Երևանի պետ. համալս.)
Commentaries: Licinius — the originally known military leader who raised and trained Tiridates III, the king of Greater Armenia. He was the Roman emperor from 308 to 324 AD. After the death of Emperor Galerius (311), in an alliance with Constantine, Licinius defeated all enemies, both were proclaimed by the emperors. However, in 324, in the war with Licinius Constantine defeated him and put him to death.

Literature:
Агатангелос. История Армении. Пер. с древнеарм., вступ. статья и комментарий К.С. Тер-Давтян и С.С. Аревшатяна. Ер., Наири, 2004. - с. 26, 29, 30, 32, 33, 56.
Ագաթանգեղոս. Հայոց պատմություն / Քննական բնագիրը Գ. Տեր-Մկըրտչյանի և Ս. Կանայանցի; Աշխարհաբար թարգմ. և ծանոթագր. Ա. Ն. Տեր-Ղևոնդյանի. — Եր,։ Երևանի Համալս. Հրատ., 1983. — էջ. 16, 17, 24-27, 30-33, 76, 77. — (Ուսանողի գ-րան/Երևանի պետ. համալս.)
Commentaries:
Khosrov II (III century AD) — the king of Greater Armenia from the Arsacid dynasty, the son of Trdat II and the father of Tiridates III (under whose reign Christianity became the official religion of Greater Armenia). Khosrov II is known for its raids on the possessions of the Sassanids, who overthrew the Arsacids from the throne in the Parthian Empire and seized power in Persia. Khosrov II was killed by Anak (the father of Gregory the Illuminator), sent by the Sasanid ruler Artashir Papakan for the purpose of murder.

A number of researchers (N. Garsoyan, R. Hovannisian) note that Armenian sources often confuse the story of Khosrov II and his grandfather Khosrov I.

Literature:
Агатангелос. История Армении. Пер. с древнеарм., вступ. статья и комментарий К.С. Тер-Давтян и С.С. Аревшатяна. Ер., Наири, 2004. - с. 77, 78, 225, 226, 232, 234, 238, 239, 242.
Ագաթանգեղոս. Հայոց պատմություն / Քննական բնագիրը Գ. Տեր-Մկըրտչյանի և Ս. Կանայանցի; Աշխարհաբար թարգմ. և ծանոթագր. Ա. Ն. Տեր-Ղևոնդյանի. — Եր,։ Երևանի Համալս. Հրատ., 1983. — էջ. 122, 123, 430, 431, 444, 445, 448, 449, 456-459, 464, 465. — (Ուսանողի գ-րան/Երևանի պետ. համալս.)
Commentaries: Khosrovidukht —  the Armenian princess, the daughter of Khosrov II and the sister of Tiridates III. Hosrovidukht is connected with the tradition according to which she had a vision that it it is necessary to release Gregory the Illuminator, imprisoned in a deep dungeon, and only Gregory will be able to cure the disease and rid the demons of Trdat III, his relatives and subjects.

Literature:
Агатангелос. История Армении. Пер. с древнеарм., вступ. статья и комментарий К.С. Тер-Давтян и С.С. Аревшатяна. Ер., Наири, 2004. - с. 245.

Commentaries: Kirakos (Kiwrakos) — one of the students of Gregory the Illuminator from the children of pagan priests, ordained in bishops in one of the edges of Armenia.

Literature:

Commentaries: Constantine the Great — the Roman emperor (306-337). In 313 he published The Edict of Milan on religious tolerance, and in 330 the Christianity in the Roman Empire was proclaimed as the state religion.

Literature:
Агатангелос. История Армении. Пер. с древнеарм., вступ. статья и комментарий К.С. Тер-Давтян и С.С. Аревшатяна. Ер., Наири, 2004. - с. 250.
Ագաթանգեղոս. Հայոց պատմություն / Քննական բնագիրը Գ. Տեր-Մկըրտչյանի և Ս. Կանայանցի; Աշխարհաբար թարգմ. և ծանոթագր. Ա. Ն. Տեր-Ղևոնդյանի. — Եր,։ Երևանի Համալս. Հրատ., 1983. — էջ. 482, 483. — (Ուսանողի գ-րան/Երևանի պետ. համալս.)
Commentaries: Constantius Chlorus — the Roman emperor as Caesar in 293–305, as August in 305–306. He was the father of Constantine the Great and the founder of the Constantinian dynasty.

Literature:
Агатангелос. История Армении. Пер. с древнеарм., вступ. статья и комментарий К.С. Тер-Давтян и С.С. Аревшатяна. Ер., Наири, 2004. - с. 245.

Commentaries: Hovhannes — one of the students of Gregory the Illuminator from the children of pagan priests, ordained in bishops in one of the edges of Armenia.

Literature:
Агатангелос. История Армении. Пер. с древнеарм., вступ. статья и комментарий К.С. Тер-Давтян и С.С. Аревшатяна. Ер., Наири, 2004. - с. 60, 62, 65, 66, 68-72, 74-77, 81, 219, 224, 226.
Ագաթանգեղոս. Հայոց պատմություն / Քննական բնագիրը Գ. Տեր-Մկըրտչյանի և Ս. Կանայանցի; Աշխարհաբար թարգմ. և ծանոթագր. Ա. Ն. Տեր-Ղևոնդյանի. — Եր,։ Երևանի Համալս. Հրատ., 1983. — էջ. 84-87, 90, 91, 96-99, 102-111, 114-121, 128-131, 416, 417, 426, 427, 430-433. — (Ուսանողի գ-րան/Երևանի պետ. համալս.)
Commentaries: St. Hripsime — a pupil of St. Gayane of royal lineage in the Convent of St. Paul in Rome, the early Christian Armenian saint and martyr, who fled along with the 37 virgin from Diocletian due to the reluctance of St. Hripsime to marry the emperor and executed by order of Tiridates III because of a similar refusal to the king of Greater Armenia.

Literature:
Агатангелос. История Армении. Пер. с древнеарм., вступ. статья и комментарий К.С. Тер-Давтян и С.С. Аревшатяна. Ер., Наири, 2004. - с. 234, 235, 239.
Ագաթանգեղոս. Հայոց պատմություն / Քննական բնագիրը Գ. Տեր-Մկըրտչյանի և Ս. Կանայանցի; Աշխարհաբար թարգմ. և ծանոթագր. Ա. Ն. Տեր-Ղևոնդյանի. — Եր,։ Երևանի Համալս. Հրատ., 1983. — էջ. 448-451, 458, 459. — (Ուսանողի գ-րան/Երևանի պետ. համալս.)
Commentaries: Leontius of Caesarea — the Metropolitan and Archbishop of Caesarea in Cappadocia, who ordered Gregory the Illuminator in bishops in Caesarea (Mazaca).

Literature:
Агатангелос. История Армении. Пер. с древнеарм., вступ. статья и комментарий К.С. Тер-Давтян и С.С. Аревшатяна. Ер., Наири, 2004. - с. 250.
Ագաթանգեղոս. Հայոց պատմություն / Քննական բնագիրը Գ. Տեր-Մկըրտչյանի և Ս. Կանայանցի; Աշխարհաբար թարգմ. և ծանոթագր. Ա. Ն. Տեր-Ղևոնդյանի. — Եր,։ Երևանի Համալս. Հրատ., 1983. — էջ. 482, 483. — (Ուսանողի գ-րան/Երևանի պետ. համալս.)
Commentaries:
Marcianus — a certain Roman ruler mentioned in the "History of Armenia" by Agatangelos along with Diocletian, Maximian, Licinius and Maxentius, who were defeated by Constantine the Great.

A. Gutschmid believes that an error crept here and Martirianus is meant, the co-rule of the Emperor of Licinius. The name Martirianus is found in the Tiflis edition of Agatangelos from 1883 (Gutschmied. s. 41-42)

Literature:
Агатангелос. История Армении. Пер. с древнеарм., вступ. статья и комментарий К.С. Тер-Давтян и С.С. Аревшатяна. Ер., Наири, 2004. - с. 250.
Ագաթանգեղոս. Հայոց պատմություն / Քննական բնագիրը Գ. Տեր-Մկըրտչյանի և Ս. Կանայանցի; Աշխարհաբար թարգմ. և ծանոթագր. Ա. Ն. Տեր-Ղևոնդյանի. — Եր,։ Երևանի Համալս. Հրատ., 1983. — էջ. 482, 483. — (Ուսանողի գ-րան/Երևանի պետ. համալս.)
Commentaries: Maxentius — the Roman emperor (306-312), son of Maximian. Taking advantage of the discontent caused in Rome by the fiscal measures of the Emperor Galerius, he seized power with the help of the Praetorians and convinced his father, who renounced the throne, again sit on the throne. The Emperor Severus, who opposed Maxentius, was defeated by him and killed. Galerius’ campaign also ended in failure. Having strengthened in Rome, Maxentius forced his father to leave Gaul and indulged in cruelty and debauchery. In the war with Constantine, he was defeated and drowned in the Tiber during the escape. His two sons were executed by Constantine.

Literature:
Агатангелос. История Армении. Пер. с древнеарм., вступ. статья и комментарий К.С. Тер-Давтян и С.С. Аревшатяна. Ер., Наири, 2004. - с. 250.
Ագաթանգեղոս. Հայոց պատմություն / Քննական բնագիրը Գ. Տեր-Մկըրտչյանի և Ս. Կանայանցի; Աշխարհաբար թարգմ. և ծանոթագր. Ա. Ն. Տեր-Ղևոնդյանի. — Եր,։ Երևանի Համալս. Հրատ., 1983. — էջ. 482, 483. — (Ուսանողի գ-րան/Երևանի պետ. համալս.)
Commentaries:
Maximian (nicknamed Herculius) — the Roman emperor (285-310). Diocletian, upon joining the throne, made Maximian Caesar (co-ruler), and after his victory over the rebellious peasants in Gaul gave him the title of Augustus (286). In the division of the empire Maximian received Africa, Spain and made Mediolanum (Milan) with his residence. Successfully fought with the Germans. He diligently supported the persecution begun by Diocletian on Christians. Together with Diocletian in 305 he renounced the throne, but in 307 he again sat on the throne, later retired to Gaul. He gave his daughter for Constantine, but then he proclaimed himself an emperor and rebelled against his father-in-law, was captured (308) and spared. Then he organized a conspiracy against Constantine, who was discovered by his daughter Fausta.

In 310 he was executed. Not to be confused with another emperor Maximinus Daza (305-312), who in 311 waged a war against Christian Armenia and was defeated by the Armenians (see: Eusebius Caesarea, pp. 49-53).

Literature:
Агатангелос. История Армении. Пер. с древнеарм., вступ. статья и комментарий К.С. Тер-Давтян и С.С. Аревшатяна. Ер., Наири, 2004. - с. 245.
Ագաթանգեղոս. Հայոց պատմություն / Քննական բնագիրը Գ. Տեր-Մկըրտչյանի և Ս. Կանայանցի; Աշխարհաբար թարգմ. և ծանոթագր. Ա. Ն. Տեր-Ղևոնդյանի. — Եր,։ Երևանի Համալս. Հրատ., 1983. — էջ. 470, 471. — (Ուսանողի գ-րան/Երևանի պետ. համալս.)
Commentaries: Movses — one of the students of Gregory the Illuminator from the children of pagan priests, ordained in bishops in one of the edges of Armenia.

Commentaries: Sasan — the Supreme Priest of the Anahita Temple in the city of Istakhr, the grandfather of Artashir I, the eponym of the Sasanian dynasty.

Literature:
Агатангелос. История Армении. Пер. с древнеарм., вступ. статья и комментарий К.С. Тер-Давтян и С.С. Аревшатяна. Ер., Наири, 2004. - с. 29.
Ագաթանգեղոս. Հայոց պատմություն / Քննական բնագիրը Գ. Տեր-Մկըրտչյանի և Ս. Կանայանցի; Աշխարհաբար թարգմ. և ծանոթագր. Ա. Ն. Տեր-Ղևոնդյանի. — Եր,։ Երևանի Համալս. Հրատ., 1983. — էջ. 24, 25. — (Ուսանողի գ-րան/Երևանի պետ. համալս.)
Commentaries: Vologases V (Vagharsh) — the King of Armenia, and then Parthia (207-8 — 222-23) from the Arsacid dynasty.

Literature:
Агатангелос. История Армении. Пер. с древнеарм., вступ. статья и комментарий К.С. Тер-Давтян и С.С. Аревшатяна. Ер., Наири, 2004. - с. 248, 249.
Ագաթանգեղոս. Հայոց պատմություն / Քննական բնագիրը Գ. Տեր-Մկըրտչյանի և Ս. Կանայանցի; Աշխարհաբար թարգմ. և ծանոթագր. Ա. Ն. Տեր-Ղևոնդյանի. — Եր,։ Երևանի Համալս. Հրատ., 1983. — էջ. 478, 479. — (Ուսանողի գ-րան/Երևանի պետ. համալս.)
Commentaries: Vrtanes I — the eldest son of Gregory the Illuminator, the Armenian Catholicos (333-341).

Literature:
Агатангелос. История Армении. Пер. с древнеарм., вступ. статья и комментарий К.С. Тер-Давтян и С.С. Аревшатяна. Ер., Наири, 2004. - с. 56, 248.
Ագաթանգեղոս. Հայոց պատմություն / Քննական բնագիրը Գ. Տեր-Մկըրտչյանի և Ս. Կանայանցի; Աշխարհաբար թարգմ. և ծանոթագր. Ա. Ն. Տեր-Ղևոնդյանի. — Եր,։ Երևանի Համալս. Հրատ., 1983. — էջ. 76, 77, 478, 479. — (Ուսանողի գ-րան/Երևանի պետ. համալս.)
Commentaries: Tachat — Armenian nakharar from the descendants of Gushar Haykazuni, was appointed by Tiridates III as the ishkhan in the Ashotsk region. According to the "History of Armenia" by Agatangelos, Tachat was the son-in-law of sparapet Artawan; Movses Khorenatsi reports that Tachat is the son-in-law of sparapet Artawazd Mandakuni (probably Aratawazd Mandakuni and Artawan are the same person).

Literature:
Агатангелос. История Армении. Пер. с древнеарм., вступ. статья и комментарий К.С. Тер-Давтян и С.С. Аревшатяна. Ер., Наири, 2004. - с. 245.
Ագաթանգեղոս. Հայոց պատմություն / Քննական բնագիրը Գ. Տեր-Մկըրտչյանի և Ս. Կանայանցի; Աշխարհաբար թարգմ. և ծանոթագր. Ա. Ն. Տեր-Ղևոնդյանի. — Եր,։ Երևանի Համալս. Հրատ., 1983. — էջ. 470, 471. — (Ուսանողի գ-րան/Երևանի պետ. համալս.)
Commentaries: Tirikes — one of the students of Gregory the Illuminator from the children of pagan priests, ordained in bishops in one of the edges of Armenia.

Literature:
Агатангелос. История Армении. Пер. с древнеарм., вступ. статья и комментарий К.С. Тер-Давтян и С.С. Аревшатяна. Ер., Наири, 2004. - с. 25-28, 33-36, 51, 55-59, 63, 65, 68, 70, 75, 225, 226, 230, 232-234, 238-239, 241, 243, 248-255.
Ագաթանգեղոս. Հայոց պատմություն / Քննական բնագիրը Գ. Տեր-Մկըրտչյանի և Ս. Կանայանցի; Աշխարհաբար թարգմ. և ծանոթագր. Ա. Ն. Տեր-Ղևոնդյանի. — Եր,։ Երևանի Համալս. Հրատ., 1983. — էջ. 16-19, 22, 23, 32-39, 68, 69, 76-79, 82, 83, 92, 93, 96, 97, 102, 103, 106, 107, 116, 117, 428-431, 440, 441, 444-449, 456-459, 462, 463, 466, 467, 476-481, 484-493. — (Ուսանողի գ-րան/Երևանի պետ. համալս.)
Commentaries: Tiridates III the Great — the King of Greater Armenia from the Arsacid dynasty (298-330), in which Christianity was adopted as an official religion in Armenia in 301.

Literature:
Агатангелос. История Армении. Пер. с древнеарм., вступ. статья и комментарий К.С. Тер-Давтян и С.С. Аревшатяна. Ер., Наири, 2004. - с. 78, 79.
Ագաթանգեղոս. Հայոց պատմություն / Քննական բնագիրը Գ. Տեր-Մկըրտչյանի և Ս. Կանայանցի; Աշխարհաբար թարգմ. և ծանոթագր. Ա. Ն. Տեր-Ղևոնդյանի. — Եր,։ Երևանի Համալս. Հրատ., 1983. — էջ. 122-125. — (Ուսանողի գ-րան/Երևանի պետ. համալս.)
Commentaries: Ota — the Armenian nakharar, who was instructed to rescue Gregory the Illuminator from the deep dungeon. Movses Khorenatsi reports that he was from the Amatuni family and the teacher of Khosrovidukht, the daughter of King Khosrov and the sister Tiridates III.

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 344.
Commentaries: Armenian naχarar (prince of Gnuni) that was sent with other princes to Caesaria to consecrate Yusik (I) as a patriarch

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 344.
Commentaries: Roman count sent together with Valens ca. 369 to reestablish Aršak II's son Pap on the Armenian throne after the Persian occupation of Armenia, also responsible (together with Terentius) for the young king's murder

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 344.
Commentaries: Bishop during the reign of Xosrov III/IV

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 344 – 345.
Commentaries: Persian general related to the Amenian Aršakuni dynasty

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 345 – 346.
Commentaries: Bishop of Manazkert. He got Manazkert with lands around it and around Euphrates as a reward for his mission to the Ordnuni and the Manawazean, fighting with each other and afflicting the whole country. In the 3rd (ch. 17), 5th and the 6th book his descendants (whom Nina G. Garsoїan calls Ałbianids) are described

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 346 – 347.
Commentaries: Senior naχarar (noble) family of presumed Iranian, Caspio-Median descent, with the domain in Artaz in Vaspurakan

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 347 – 348.
Commentaries: Father of Gregory the Illuminator

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 348.
Commentaries: Persian general sent by Šāhpuhr II against Aršak II. Despite the fact that he is said to have been killed in the first campaign (4th book, ch. 22), he should be identified with the homonymous Persian defeated and killed in ch. 27 of the 4th book

Literature:
«История Армении» Фавстоса Бузанда. Пер. с др.-арм. и коммент. М.А. Геворгяна, под ред. С.Т. Еремяна, вступит. ст. Л.С. Хачикяна. Ереван, 1953. 

The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 348 – 349.
Commentaries: Lord of Siwnikʿ, father of Pʿaṙanjem and father-in-law of Aršak II, kinsman of the Mamikonean that accompanied Pʿaṙēn and Nersēs I to their consecration at Caesaria, was an ambassador to the Byzantine court. Governor of Armenia in the interregnum before the accession of Aršak III. He is also shown as provoking the thirty years' war between Armenia and Persia to the ultimate destruction of the Armenian kingdom, especially Siwnikʿ, his principality

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 349.
Commentaries: Persian commander defeated and killed by Vasak Mamikonean

Literature:
«История Армении» Фавстоса Бузанда. Пер. с др.-арм. и коммент. М.А. Геворгяна, под ред. С.Т. Еремяна, вступит. ст. Л.С. Хачикяна. Ереван, 1953. 

The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 350.
Commentaries: Great naχarar family descended from Orontids and dynasts of Sophenē. They ruled over the district of Ałbak in the upper valley of the Great Zab with their center at Hadamakert. In Buzandaran, the role of Arcruni is relatively negative after the survival and vengeance of Šawasp for the massacre of his kinsmen, as it then centers at the career of the archtraitor Meružan

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 350.
Commentaries: The great heresiarch condemned at the First Council of Nicaea in 325, where St. James of Nisibis revealed his visions

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 351.
Commentaries: Younger son and immediate successor of Gregory the Illuminator as primate of Greater Armenia. Attendant of the Council in Nicaea, representing Armenia. Was buried either at Gregory's domain in Tʿil in Ekełeacʿ (3rd book, ch. 2) or near the church in Tʿordan of Daranałikʿ (3rd book, ch. 14)

Literature:
«История Армении» Фавстоса Бузанда. Пер. с др.-арм. и коммент. М.А. Геворгяна, под ред. С.Т. Еремяна, вступит. ст. Л.С. Хачикяна. Ереван, 1953. 

The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 352 – 353.
Commentaries: King of Armenia (Tiran's successor), major protagonist of Buzandaran Patmutʿyunkʿ. On the one hand, he is the "true lord" of Armenia, a Christian king opposed to rebellious naχarars, having showed valor in the Persian war. On the other hand, he is condemned for the construction of the evil city of Aršakawan and his nephew Gnel's murder. Married to the Roman Olympias and Pʿaṙanjem of Siwnikʿ (mother of his successor Pap).His growing disagreement with the Armenian church led to the departure and exile of St. Nersēs, the patriarch. His attempt to maneuver between Rome and Persia ended in his overthrow and captivity after Jovian's peace of 363

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 353 – 354.
Commentaries: Elder son of king Pap and queen Zarmanduχt, enthroned with his brother Vałaršak under the regency of their mother by the sparapet (commander-in-chief) Manul Mamikonean, who gave him his daughter Vardanduχt in marriage. When Persians (under king Šāhpuhr III) attacked Armenia, he fled to Ekełeacʿ, where he ruled after the partition of Armenia between Rome and the Persians and died soon thereafter

Literature:
«История Армении» Фавстоса Бузанда. Пер. с др.-арм. и коммент. М.А. Геворгяна, под ред. С.Т. Еремяна, вступит. ст. Л.С. Хачикяна. Ереван, 1953. 

The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 354 – 355.
Commentaries: Armenian ruling dynasty of the 4th century, junior branch of the Parthian royal house of Iran. First appeared in Armenia in 12 AD (king of kings Vonones). The overthrow of the senior branch in Iran in 224 led to the blood feud between the junior Armenian branch and the new Sasanian dynasty. Deeply iranized in ethos and manners, Arsacids were still dependent on Rome and aligned their policy with Constantinople against Persia, also followed Arianizig policies of Constantine I's successors, causing conflicts with Armenian church under orthodox Gregorid patriarchs (though Aršakuni often married into the patriarchal house)

Literature:
«История Армении» Фавстоса Бузанда. Пер. с др.-арм. и коммент. М.А. Геворгяна, под ред. С.Т. Еремяна, вступит. ст. Л.С. Хачикяна. Ереван, 1953. 

The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 356.
Commentaries: Nahapet (the head) of the Kamsarakan house, lord of Širak and Aršarunikʿ; son-in-law of the Mamikonean. He accompanied the patriarchs Pʿaṙēn and Nersēs I to the consecration at Caesaria. After the imprisonment of king Tiran, he was sent with Andovk Siwni to seek the help of the Byzantine court and was installed as governor of Armenia by the emperor in the interregnum preceding the return of the Aršakuni heir Aršak II

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 356 – 357.
Commentaries: Sepuh (noble member) of the Mamikonean house,  father of the sparapet (commander-in-chief) Manuēl Mamikonean and of his brother Koms

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 357.
Commentaries: Sepuh (noble member) of the Mamikonean house, son of Manuēl Mamikonean, whom he succeeded as sparapet (commander-in-chief)

Literature:
«История Армении» Фавстоса Бузанда. Пер. с др.-арм. и коммент. М.А. Геворгяна, под ред. С.Т. Еремяна, вступит. ст. Л.С. Хачикяна. Ереван, 1953. 

The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 357 – 358.
Commentaries: Last Parthian king of Iran from the Aršakuni senior line, defeated and killed by the Sasanian Ardašīr I ca. 224. Armenian Arsacids regarded Artewan as their kinsman and Ardašīr (who started the new Sasanian dynasty after the murder) as an usurper

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 358.
Commentaries: Prince of Vanand  and presumed successor of Vorotʿ. He was sent together with some princes to bring Daniēl to king Tiran for further consecration

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 358.
Commentaries: First attested sparapet (commander-in-chief) of Greater Armenia, father of his successor Vačʿē I Mamikonean

Literature:
«История Армении» Фавстоса Бузанда. Пер. с др.-арм. и коммент. М.А. Геворгяна, под ред. С.Т. Еремяна, вступит. ст. Л.С. Хачикяна. Ереван, 1953. 

The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 358 – 359.
Commentaries: Sepuh (noble member) of the Mamikonean house, son of the sparapet (commander-in-chief) Vačʿē I. He inherited this office as a child, shared it with his kinsman Vasak. He probably reached maturity by the end of Tiran's reign, since his daughters are presumably referred to

Literature:
«История Армении» Фавстоса Бузанда. Пер. с др.-арм. и коммент. М.А. Геворгяна, под ред. С.Т. Еремяна, вступит. ст. Л.С. Хачикяна. Ереван, 1953. 

The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 359.
Commentaries: Sepuh (noble member) of the Mamikonean house, son of Vačʿē II, who distinguished himself despite his extreme youth at the final defeat of Meruž an Arcruni in which his father was killed

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 359.
Commentaries: Bishop of Basean. He may be identified with Artitʿēs, the eighth disciple of Gregory the Illuminator (according to Agatʿangełos)

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 359.
Commentaries: Hermit and disciple of St. Gind

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 360.
Commentaries: Patriarch (senior bishop) of Armenia, one of the descendants descendants of Bishop Ałbianos of Manazkert. Kinsman of Zawēn and Šahak/Yusik

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 360.
Commentaries: Son-in-law and successor of Xad of Marag as bishop of Bagrewand and Aršarunikʿ

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 360 – 361.
Commentaries: Son of the patriarch Yusik I, great-grandson of Gregory the Illuminator, father of St. Nersēs. With his twin-brother Pap, he was considered to be unworthy to assume the patriarchal office of his family. They both rejected it in favor of military careers. It led to the first temporary hiatus in the hereditary transmision of the patriarchate in the Gregorid house

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 361.
Commentaries: Armenian naχarar (nobleman), prince of Gołtʿn that was sent with other princes to Caesaria to consecrate Yusik (I) as a patriarch

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 361.
Commentaries: Early disciple of Christ, known for her "good work and acts of mercy", resurrected by St. Peter after her death. Her story (from the Acts of Apostles) is told by Nersēs I when preaching. Aycemnik is the Armenian form of her name Tabitha/Dorcas

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 361 – 362.
Commentaries: Nahapet (the head) of the house of Siwnikʿ who survived the Persian massacre and returned to regain his domain with the help of the sparapet (commander-in-chief) Manuēl Mamikonean. As Manuēl 's companion-in-arms, Babik helped him to kill the traitor Meružan Arcruni

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 362.
Commentaries: Naχarar (noble) family. The only member mentioned is Kiškēn accompanying Nersēs I on his embassy to the Byzantine court in 358

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 362.
Commentaries: Sepuh (noble member) of the Mamikonean, brother of the nahapet (the head of the noble house) Vardan and the sparapet (commander-in-chief) Vasak

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 362.
Commentaries: Armenian commander and hereditary aspet (commander-of the-cavalry) of the realm from Trdat the Great to the beginning of that of Aršak II, nahapet (the head) of the Bagratuni house (the only house member mentioned in the books). Companion-in-arms of the sparapet (commander-in-chief) Vačʿē I Mamikonean in the Mazkʿutʿkʿ war (with northern Iranic barbarians)

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 362 – 363.
Commentaries: Major naχarar (noble) and royal house of Armenia and Iberia, holding the district of Sper and the hereditary offices of royal coronants and aspets (comanders-of the-cavalry). The only member mentioned is Bagrat, companion-in-arms of Vačʿē I Mamikonean in the Mazkʿutʿkʿ war (with northern Iranic barbarians)

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 363 – 364.
Commentaries: Marcher-lord (bdeašχ) of Ałjnikʿ(senior in the rank of the four bdeašχs) who mounted a rebellion against Xostov Kotak. After Bakur's defeat and death his domans were granted to Vałinak Siwni

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 364.
Commentaries: Aršakuni princess, wife of Atʿanaginēs and mother of the patriarch St. Nerses, alao sister of king Tiran

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 364.
Commentaries: The great Cappadocian father and bishop of Caesaria in Cappadocia (370 - 379), that appears in the books only through the anachronistic transposition of some episodes of his life, especially the refusal to cure the son of the emperor Valens, to that of St. Nerses, or throught the interpolation of such episodes into the narrative

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 365.
Commentaries: Nahapet (the head) of the Sahaṙuni house and tutor (dayeak) of king Varazdat, who attempted to transmit to him the office of sparapet (commander-in-chief) hereditary in the Mamikonean house. He murdered the sparapet Mušēł Mamikonean with the connivance of the king, but was himself with his son killed by Mušēł's kinsman, Manuēl Mamikonean

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 365.
Commentaries: Persian naaχarar (nobleman) defeated and killed by Vasak Mamikonean

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 365.
Commentaries: Naχarar (noble) family holding the district north and west of Lake Van, which bore its name. The entire family was annihiliated under Xosrov Kotak as a consequence of the treson of its nahapet (the head of the family) Databē, and its posessions passed to the royal treasury

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 384.
Commentaries: The first Christian Roman emperor that presided the Council of Nicaea and made an alliance with Trdat, king of Greater Armenia

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 366 – 367.
Commentaries: Armenian prelate illegitimately consecrated at the order of Aršak II during the exile of St. Nersēs. His name can be regarded as an epithet meaning "man of nothing, slave of slaves of the king"

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 367.
Commentaries: Syrian bishop, supervisor of the shrine at Aštišat and missionary to Persia, installed as overseer of the churches of Tarōn by Gregory the Illuminator, whose disciple he is said to have been

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 367.
Commentaries: Armenian naχarar (nobleman), great prince of Copʿkʿ who accompanied St. Nersēls to his consecration at Caesaria

Literature:
«История Армении» Фавстоса Бузанда. Пер. с др.-арм. и коммент. М.А. Геворгяна, под ред. С.Т. Еремяна, вступит. ст. Л.С. Хачикяна. Ереван, 1953. 

The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 368.
Commentaries: Commander of the mounted shield-bearers in Manuēl Mamikonean's army in the battle against king Varazdat; killed Garegin Ṙštuni

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 368.
Commentaries: Armenian naχarar (nobleman), prince of Hašteankʿ who supported king Xosrov Kotak during the revolt of the marcher-lord (bdeašχ) Bakur. Presumably succeeded by Gnitʿ

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 368.
Commentaries: Nahapet (the head) of the Bznuni house and commander of the Armenian army, whose betrayal of king Xosrov Kotak in the war against Persians led to his executions and the extirpation of his entire family

Literature:
«История Армении» Фавстоса Бузанда. Пер. с др.-арм. и коммент. М.А. Геворгяна, под ред. С.Т. Еремяна, вступит. ст. Л.С. Хачикяна. Ереван, 1953. 

The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 368.
Commentaries: Persian commander, presumably related to the Armenian Mamikonean house. The same common noun "dehkan" is a title of the "head of the village"

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 369.
Commentaries: Nahapet (the head) of the Gntʿuni housewho accompanied Nersēs I on his embassy to the Byzantine court in 358

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 369.
Commentaries: Naχarar (noble) family of unknown origin. The only member mentioned is Varaz, who was sent to bring Daniēl to king Tiran for further consecration

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 369.
Commentaries: Persian commander (vsemakan), possibly from the Iraian Kavian house

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 369 – 370.
Commentaries: Armenian naχarar (nobleman), eunuch and hayr-mardpet (supervisor of all royal fortresses) of the realm under Tiran and Aršak II. He was granted a title of prince of Angełtun and of governor of Angeł and of Bnabeł in Copʿkʿ. After his deportation to Persia, he served Šāhpuhr II in the Kʿušan war, obtained the reward of visiting Aršak in Anyuš and commited a suicide with the king

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 370.
Commentaries: Greek anchorite and disciple of St. Daniēl, who designated him as missionary to Ałjnikʿ and Copʿkʿ Mec. One of the witnesses of the miraculous assumption of St. Nersēs, though the details of hi ascetic life fit more into the southern eremitic circle of St. Daniēl than into more officially structured Hellenizing world of St. Nersēs

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 370 – 371.
Commentaries: Chief executor (dahčapet) of Aršak II

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 371.
Commentaries: Bishop of Caesaria (362 - 370) between Dianios and St. Basil. His early disagreements with St. Basil led to the retirement of the latter from Caesaria in 358, but the former recalled him in 365 in the face of Valens's Arianizing persecution of the orthodox party and made him the coadjutor of the see

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 371.
Commentaries: Armenian commander and companion-in-arms of the sparapet (commander-in-chief) Vačʿē I Mamikonean, kinsman of Mehandak Ṙštuni

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 371.
Commentaries: Nahapet (the head) of the Ṙštuni house, husband of Hamazaspuhi Mamikonean, the sister of Vardan Mamikonean whom he abandoned during Šāhpuhr II's conquest of Armenia. He returned under king Pap and was killed in the battle between king Varazdat and the sparapet (commander-in-chief) Manuēl Mamikonean

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 372.
Commentaries: Nahapet (the head) of the Xoṙχoṙuni house under Aršak II in succession to Manasp and with the hereditary title of małχaz (lord, prince). He accompanied Nersēs I on his embassy to the Byzantine court in 358. Also was sent as an ambassador to Persia by Manuēl Mamikonean (regent after Varazdat's expulsion) and killed in the decisive defeat of Meružan Arcruni

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 372.
Commentaries: Virgin martyr and companion of St. Hripsime

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 372.
Commentaries: Hermit and disciple of St. Daniēl from the district of Tarōn, overseer of all Armenian eremitic communities; also maintained the classic wandering life of early anchorites until he retired with his disciple Mušē in Oskikʿ

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 373.
Commentaries: Mardpet (grand chamberlain) of Armenia under Tiran or Aršak II and under Pap, who had him executed for intrigues with Persia. The form "Głak" appears in other Armenian sources, whereas in Buzandaran forms "Dgłak" and "Dłak" (that came possibly due to a scribal error) are given

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 373.
Commentaries: Nahapet (the head) of the Anjewacʿikʿ in Vaspurakan, whose loyalty to King Pap led to his denunciation of the intrigues of the mardpet (grand chamberlain) Głak and to his own death in defense of the king at the hands of the Roman commander Terentius

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 373 – 374.
Commentaries: Sepuh (noble member) of the Aršakuni house, nephew of Aršak II. One of the hostages sent back to Armenia as a result of Nersēs I emnbassy. He was treacherously murdered by Aršak because of the slander of the king's other nephew Tiritʿ, enamoured of Gnel's wife Pʿaṙanjem

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 374.
Commentaries: Prince of Hašteankʿ and the successor of Varaz. He accompanied Yusik I to his consecration at Caesaria

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 374.
Commentaries: Naχarar (noble) house of uncertain origin but traditionally descended from the Canaanites and holding the office of master of the wardrobe. Their domain was apparently the district of Nig in Ayrarat, a branch may have a had posessions in Širak, as well

Literature:
«История Армении» Фавстоса Бузанда. Пер. с др.-арм. и коммент. М.А. Геворгяна, под ред. С.Т. Еремяна, вступит. ст. Л.С. Хачикяна. Ереван, 1953. 

The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 374 – 375.
Commentaries: Naχarar (noble) family probably of Orontid origin, identified with the office of hazarapet (chancellor), which had passed to them from the house of Anjit at the beginning of Aršak II's reign. The original domain sees to have been found around the localities of Arčēš and Berkri north and east of Lake Van in the district of Ałiovit and Aṙberani in Turuberan, also they held a land in Ayrarat

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 375.
Commentaries: Nahapet (the head) of the house of Jor/Joropʿor who accompanied Nersēs I to his consecration at Caesaria

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 375 – 376.
Commentaries: Founder of Armenian Christianity in the 4th century, son of Anak the Parthian, rescued by his nurse from the massacre of his family following the morder of Xosrov I by his father. Was buried together with his son Aristakes near the church in Tʿordan of Daranałikʿ

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 376 – 377.
Commentaries: Grandson of Gregory the Illuminator and twin brother of Yusik I, bishop of Iberia (Virkʿ) and Ałuankʿ. He went with a mission to Mazkʿutʿkʿ (northern Iranic barbarians) and was martyred by them on the plain of Vatneay

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 377.
Commentaries: Persian commander named twice: in the 4th book he was killed by Vasak Mamikonean, in the 5th book his namesake was killed later by Manuēl Mamikonean. Nina G. Garsoїan regardes them as the same person

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 377 – 378.
Commentaries: Naχarar (noble) family. The only member mentioned is Vrkēn who accompanied Nersēs I on his embassy to the Byzantine court in 358

Literature:
«История Армении» Фавстоса Бузанда. Пер. с др.-арм. и коммент. М.А. Геворгяна, под ред. С.Т. Еремяна, вступит. ст. Л.С. Хачикяна. Ереван, 1953. 

The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 378.
Commentaries: Sepuh (noble member) of the Mamikonean house, father of Hamazaspean (if it is not the same person mentioned) and Hamazaspuhi.

Literature:
«История Армении» Фавстоса Бузанда. Пер. с др.-арм. и коммент. М.А. Геворгяна, под ред. С.Т. Еремяна, вступит. ст. Л.С. Хачикяна. Ереван, 1953. 

The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 378 – 379.
Commentaries: Sepuh (noble member) of the Mamikonean house, brother of Hamazaspuhi (although in the book he can be mistaken with Hamazasp and so be Hamazaspuhi's father)

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 379.
Commentaries: Sister of the nahapet Vardan Mamikonean and stepsister of the traitor Vahan, wife of Garegin II, prince of Ṙštunikʿ. She was martyred during the Persian occupation of Armenia post 363

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 379.
Commentaries: Persian general sent by Šāhpuhr II against Aršak II, defeated and killed by Vasak Mamikonean

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 380.
Commentaries: Jewish high-priest (79 - 40 BC), son of Alexander Jannaeus. He was carried off to Babylonia by the Parthians in 40 BC, but Armenian tradition anachronisitcally has nim brought  as a captive to Armenia

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 380.
Commentaries: Sepuh (noble member) of the Mamikonean house, son of the sparapet (commander-in-chief) Manuēl, whom he supported against king Varazdat

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 381.
Commentaries: Persian general that was defeated by Vasak Mamikonean and retreated together with Meružan

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 381.
Commentaries: Virgin martyr who rejected the advances of King Trdat. She and her companions were buried at Vałaršapat by Gregory the Illuminator

Literature:
«История Армении» Фавстоса Бузанда. Пер. с др.-арм. и коммент. М.А. Геворгяна, под ред. С.Т. Еремяна, вступит. ст. Л.С. Хачикяна. Ереван, 1953. 

The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 431.
Commentaries: First know bishop of Nisibis, who is said to have said his city from the Persians. On Mt. Sararad he received wood of the Noah's ark as a gift. From the Mt. Ǝnj̆akʿisar cursed Ṙštunik for the cruelty of its ruler Manačihr. At the Council in Nicaea revealed the sackcloth worn by Constantine the Great, and an angel defending James

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 431.
Commentaries: Son of patriarch Pʿaṙēn of Aštišat, hepocritical Armenian bishop with a regrettable career described in an anticlerical and moralizing tone

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 381 – 382.
Commentaries: Prince of Kordukʿ and marcher-lord (bdeašχ) of the Assyrian March of the Armenian kingdom

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 382.
Commentaries: Naχarar (noble) family, identified with the branch of the Aršakuni house

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 382.
Commentaries: Leading naχarar (noble) family traditionally descended from the great Iranian clan of the Karēn and related to the royal Aršakuni. Lords of Aršarunikʿ and Širak, massacred under Aršak II, their domains confiscated

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 382 – 383, 433.
Commentaries: Persian commander sent together with Zik to capture the royal fortress of Artagers, entrusted with the Armenian government after Persian occupation of Armenia and killed (with Zik) by sparapet (commander-in-chief) Mušeł Mamikonean. Nina G. Garsoїan identifies this anthroponym with one of the seven great houses of Parthian Iran, one of the collateral branches of the ruling house that maintained their position under the Sasanians and were enthrusted with major offices

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 383.
Commentaries: Nahapet (the head) of the Amatuni house between Vahan and Pargew. He was sent together with some princes to bring Daniēl to king Tiran for further consecration

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 436 – 437.
Commentaries: Nahapet (the head) of the Bagean family who accompanied Nersēs I on his embassy to the Byzantine court in 358

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 383.
Commentaries: Bishop of Taykʿ; his alternate name Šahap is merely the Armenian translation of its Greek form

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 383 – 384.
Commentaries: Sepuh (noble member) of the Mamikonean house, brother of the sparapet (commander-in-chief) Manuēl, whose exile in Persia he shared and with whom he returned to Armenia

Literature:
«История Армении» Фавстоса Бузанда. Пер. с др.-арм. и коммент. М.А. Геворгяна, под ред. С.Т. Еремяна, вступит. ст. Л.С. Хачикяна. Ереван, 1953. 

The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 385 – 386.
Commentaries: Naχarar (noble) family, possibly the Gregorid holders of the patriarchal throne. They descend from the kings of the Čʿenkʿ, might also have some Persian kinsmen. In the 4th century their office was that of hereditary sparapet (commander-in-chief) of the Armenian army. The original domain of the clan appears to have been in Taykʿ, but in the 4th century they held at least part of Tarōn. After 438 they acquired the vast patriarchal lands in that district, as well as in Daranałikʿ and Ekełeacʿ through the marriage of Sahakanoyš, the daughter of the last Gregorid patriarch, Sahak I, to Hamazasp Mamikonean and thereby became the largest landholders in Greater Armenia

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 386.
Commentaries: Nahapet (the head) of the Ṙštuni house, "great prince" (mec išχan) and "lord of the realm" (ašχarhtēr)

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 386.
Commentaries: Prince of Basean and perhaps nahapet (the head) of the Orduni house

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 386.
Commentaries: Nahapet (the head) of the Xoṙχoṙuni house and małχaz (lord, prince) as the predecessor of Garǰoyl. He was sent with other princes to Caesaria to consecrate Yusik (I) as a patriarch

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 387.
Commentaries: Prince of Kołb/Kołbopʿor (in the Iberian March) that was sent with other princes to Caesaria to consecrate Yusik (I) as a patriarch

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 387.
Commentaries: Naχarar (noble) family traditionally descended from the Armenian eponymous hero Hayk like their rivals, the Ordnuni house

Literature:
«История Армении» Фавстоса Бузанда. Пер. с др.-арм. и коммент. М.А. Геворгяна, под ред. С.Т. Еремяна, вступит. ст. Л.С. Хачикяна. Ереван, 1953. 

The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 387 – 388.
Commentaries: Sepuh (the noble member) of the Mamikonean house, son of Artašēs/Artašēn and brother of Koms, with whom he returned to Armenia after serving the Sasanians in the Kušan war. He reclaimed the dignity of nahapet (the head) of his house and wrested his family's hereditary office of sparapet (commander-in-chief) from Bat Sahaṙuni. He defeated the king and drove him from Armenia, killed Bat and ruled Armenia through Zarmanduχt, Pap's widow and regent for her two minor sons. At first he was pro-Persian (even installed Suren as marzpan (governor) of Armenia), but then turned against Sasanians, drove them out of the country, put an end to the rebellion of Meružan Arcruni. Also gave his daughter Vardanduχt in marriage to king Aršak III

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 388.
Commentaries: Prince of Copʿkʿ Mec who supported Xosrov Kotak against the revolt of the marcher-lord (bdeašχ) Bakur

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 388.
Commentaries: Hermit and disciple of St. Gind

Literature:
«История Армении» Фавстоса Бузанда. Пер. с др.-арм. и коммент. М.А. Геворгяна, под ред. С.Т. Еремяна, вступит. ст. Л.С. Хачикяна. Ереван, 1953. 

The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 388.
Commentaries: The chief priest of the Christians in the Persian capital of Ctesiphon (Tizbon), that was killed together with 70 Christian priests by the order of Persian king Šapuh

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 389.
Commentaries: Persian general defeated by Vasak Mamikonean

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 390.
Commentaries: Armenian commander and companion-in-arms of the sparapet (commander-in-chief) Vačʿē in the Mazkʿutʿkʿ war (with northern Iranic barbarians) and kinsman of Garegin I Ṙštuni. He accompanied Pʿaṙēn of Aštišat to his consecration at Caesaria

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 390 – 391.
Commentaries: Nahapet (the head) of the Ṙštuni house who accompanied Nersēs I to his consecration at Caesaria and afterwards on his embassy to the Byzantine court in 358

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 391.
Commentaries: Nahapet (the head of the noble naχarar family) of Anjewacʿikʿ who accompanied Nersēs I on his embassy to the Byzantine court in 358

Literature:
«История Армении» Фавстоса Бузанда. Пер. с др.-арм. и коммент. М.А. Геворгяна, под ред. С.Т. Еремяна, вступит. ст. Л.С. Хачикяна. Ереван, 1953. 

The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 391 – 392.
Commentaries: Nahapet (the head) of the Arcruni house and the leader fo the rebellion against Aršak II and his successor. Son of Šawasp Arcruni, that was saved (together with Tačat Ṙštuni) by Artawazd and Vasak Mamikoneans and married one of their daughters. Therefore Meružan's mother comes from Mamikonean house and Mamikoneans regard him as their borther

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 392.
Commentaries: One of the two bishops of Basean

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 392.
Commentaries: Court priest, whom Pʿaṙanjem persuaded to murder Aršak II's Roman wife Olympias with the Eucharist , and who was rewarded with the grant of his native village for the crime

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 392 – 393.
Commentaries: Persian general sent against Aršak II. He was killed by armies of Vasak Mamikonean at this campaign (4th book), however a namesake reappears, only to be killed by Manuēl Mamikonean (5th book). The only thing showing that the same person is mentioned in two books, is the word "darjeal" (դառձեալ in 5th book, ch. 49) meaning "once again": this person is once again sent by the Persian king against Armenians

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 393.
Commentaries: Archdeacon of St. Nersēs

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 393.
Commentaries: Anchorite and disciple of St. Gind, can be a Syrian, as his name is given in a Syriac form "Mušē" rather than Armenian "Movsēs"

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 393.
Commentaries: Sepuh (the noble member) of the Mamikonean house who succeded his father Vasak as sparapet (commander-in-chief) and commanded azats (lowest noblemen) of the Armenian army. During Šapuh's invasion, he went to the Byzantine court to seek support for Aršak II's son Pap, whom he reestablished on the Armenian throne with the help of the imperial army. As sparapet, he drove the Persians out of Armenia and temporarily reconquered border lands that Armenia had lost after the peace of 363. He was slandered to king Pap and murdered by order of Pap's successor, Varazdat

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 394.
Commentaries: Nahapet (the head) of the Sahaṙuni house and one of the magnates accompanying Nersēs I on his embassy to the Byzantine court in 358

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 394.
Commentaries: Persian general defeated and killed by Vasak Mamikonean

Literature:
«История Армении» Фавстоса Бузанда. Пер. с др.-арм. и коммент. М.А. Геворгяна, под ред. С.Т. Еремяна, вступит. ст. Л.С. Хачикяна. Ереван, 1953. 

The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 394.
Commentaries: King of Kings of Persia (293-303), last reigning son of Šāhpuhr I. He ruled over eastern Iran and subsequently Armenia before his transfer to the royal throne of Iran.

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 394 – 395.
Commentaries: Nahapet (the head of the noble naχarar family) of Copʿkʿ Šahēi who supported Xosrov Kotak against the revolt of the marcher-lord (bdeašχ) Bakur

Literature:
«История Армении» Фавстоса Бузанда. Пер. с др.-арм. и коммент. М.А. Геворгяна, под ред. С.Т. Еремяна, вступит. ст. Л.С. Хачикяна. Ереван, 1953. 

The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 395 – 396.
Commentaries: Patriarch of Greater Armenia (353-373), son of Atʿanaginēs and Bambišn Aršakuni, great-great-grandson of Gregory the Illuminator. He was educated and probably married in Caesaria, then ran a military career and had an office of royal senekapet (chamberlain). The embassy in Byzantium (in 358) resulted in his exile. He returned to Armenia only under king Pap, though hostility between him and Pap led to the murder of the former at the instigation of the latter

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 396.
Commentaries: Nahapet (the head of the noble naχarar family) of Copʿkʿ Šahēi who accompanied Nersēs I to his consecration at Caesaria

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 396.
Commentaries: The wife of Aršak II, coming from the Roman emperor's family. She was murdered at the instigation of Pʿaṙanjem of Siwnikʿ, Aršak's other wife

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 396 – 397.
Commentaries: Naχarar (noble) family, traditionally descended from the Armenian eponymous hero Hayk like their rivals, the Manawazean

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 397.
Commentaries: Sister of the Persian king of kings Šāhpuhr II and wife of the apostate Vahan Mamikonean

Literature:
«История Армении» Фавстоса Бузанда. Пер. с др.-арм. и коммент. М.А. Геворгяна, под ред. С.Т. Еремяна, вступит. ст. Л.С. Хачикяна. Ереван, 1953. 

The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 397 – 398.
Commentaries: Son of Aršak II and Pʿaṙanjem, king of Armenia as Aršak's successor. Hostage at a Byzantine court. He returned to Armenia with the support of the sparapet (commander-in-chief) Mušeł Mamikonean and the Roman army with commander Terentius. Then his relations with the Romans worsened due to his putative claims of the Roman cities and continuation of his father's Arianizing policy that led to the murder of patriarch Nersēs I. After a brief hiatus he was succeeded by his sons Aršak III and Vałaršak under the regency of their mother Zarmanduχt and sparapet Manuēl Mamikonean

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 398.
Commentaries: Son of Yusik I, great-grandson of Gregory the Illuminator. Together with his twin brother Atʿanaginēs he was considered unworthy to assume the patricarchal house, rejected it to the military career and so caused the hiatus in the hereditary transmission of the Armenian patriarchate within Gregorids

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 398 – 399.
Commentaries: Daughter of Andovk Siwni, queen of Armenia as wife of Aršak II (prefiously she was the wife of Aršak's nephew Gnel) and mother of his son and successor Pap. Being jealous, she sent Mrǰiwnik, the court priest, to kill Aršak's Roman wife Olympias

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 399 – 400.
Commentaries: Patriarch of Greater Armenia (348 - 352?) after murders of Yusik and Daniēl. Father of regrettable bishop Yohan. After his short pontificate was buried in the agarak (estate) in Taron, where he came from. Nina G. Garsoїan identifies the place of his burial with the holy site of Aštišat (Gregorid family plot) and so regards Pʿaṙēn as a collateral or minor member of the Gregorids.

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 400.
Commentaries: Presumably the nahapet (the head) of the Amatuni house following Karēn

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 400.
Commentaries: Name of the Iberian dynasty claiming descent from an eponymous Pʿaṙnawaz, rather than an individual

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 400 – 401.
Commentaries: Bishop of Byzantine origin, that consecrated Nersēs I as deacon, buried Nersēs I, that was already a patriarch, and probably was member of Nersēs's household (6th book)

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 401.
Commentaries: Presumable reference to the author of "Buzandaran Patmutʿyunkʿ" in the colophon following the 3rd book

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 401.
Commentaries: Nahapet (the head) of the Siwni house and treacherous senekapet (chamberlain) of king Tiran

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 401 – 402.
Commentaries: Deacon who shared the exile of Nersēs I. He can be indentified with Aṙostom, the hermit brother of bishop Pʿawstos (member of Nersēs's household), though this identification is a bit controversial

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 402.
Commentaries: Naχarar (noble) family ruling the homonymous district on the southern shore of Lake Van. They were themselves decimated at the end of king Tiran's reign, if not earlier. Tačat and Garegin II Ṙštuni married into the Mamikonean house

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 403.
Commentaries: Patriarch of Greater Armenia, descendant of Ałbianos of Manazkert, successor of Pʿaṙēn of Aštišat. Consecrated at Caesaria

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 403 – 404.
Commentaries: Armenian partriarch/senior bishop from the southern district of Korčēkʿ/Korčaykʿ, successor of Zawēn. His pontificate lasted two years

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 404.
Commentaries: Naharar (noble) house whose domain is in Ayrarat on the border of Širak. The house members served as tutors (dayeaks) for minor Aršakuni and were granted to be sparapets (commanders-in-chief) for a brief time at the end of Aršakuni period, though they did not keep it

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 404 – 405.
Commentaries: Nahapet (the head) of the house of Anjewacʿikʿ who accompanied Yusik I to his consecration at Caesaria

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 406 – 407.
Commentaries: Persian king of kings (309 - 379), under whom the Sasanian dynasty reached its full extent. During the first campaignes of the war against Romans he failed to conquer Nisibis (Mcbin). After peace of 363 he abandoned Greater Armenia (so it was deurbanized and devastated) some southern Satrapies and Nisibis to Sasanians. At the end of his reign the war began anew

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 405.
Commentaries: Prince of Anjit who abandoned Aršak II after the Roman-Persian peace of 363 and withdrew to the Byzantine territory

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 405.
Commentaries: Syrian anchorite and disciple of St. Daniēl who designated him as missionary to Kordukʿ and witness with St. Epipʿan of St. Nersēs's miraculous assumption

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 405.
Commentaries: Sepuh (noble member) of the house of Siwni, Babik's younger brother

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 405 – 406.
Commentaries: Sepuh (noble member) of the Mamikonean house, son of the apostle Vahan and the Sasanian princess Ormizduχt. He killed his parents because of their support of Zoroastrism in Armenia, participated in Manuēl Mamikonean's victory over his kinsman Meružan Arcruni

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 406.
Commentaries: King of Armenia, killer of apostle Thaddeus, founder of Mcurn. As a member of the Aršakuni house, he is buried the royal necropolis of Ani in Daranałikʿ

Literature: The Epic Histories Attributed to Pʽawstos Buzand / Translation and Commentary by Nina G. Garsoїan. Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1989. P. 406.
Commentaries: King of the Mazkʿutʿkʿ, Aršakuni kinsman of the Armenian kings and killer of St. Grigoris
